importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks when the White House announced its plan to use tariff revenue to fund WIC during the government shutdown, highlighting the urgency and timing of the policy decision.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The fiscal year 2026 began on October 1, 2025, and the government shutdown occurred during this period, directly affecting WIC’s funding due to lack of congressional appropriations.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration proposed using tariff revenue, specifically from Section 32 and Section 232 tariffs, to fund the WIC program during the government shutdown.
WIC, which serves nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children, was at risk of shutting down due to the lack of funding from Congress.
The White House claimed that redirecting tariff funds to WIC is a 'creative solution' to prevent program closure, though legal experts questioned whether Congress has authorized such a transfer.
The National WIC Association expressed concern over short-term uncertainty and lack of clarity on funding amounts, distribution timelines, and sustainability.
Bipartisan support for WIC has increased, with Republican figures like House Speaker Mike Johnson criticizing Democrats for contributing to the shutdown’s impact on vulnerable families.
Despite the federal government shutdown, WIC has received up to $150 million in contingency funds and state-level rebates from infant formula manufacturers.
WIC enrollment has risen, reaching nearly 6.9 million people in May 2025, indicating growing need for sustained funding.

Federal funding for WIC is capped, and the pending budget bills differ: House bill maintains current funding at $7.6 billion, while Senate bill provides $8.2 billion, both insufficient for long-term stability.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive office of the President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House announced and implemented a plan to use tariff revenue to fund WIC during the shutdown, demonstrating executive action in response to a legislative impasse.

namedEntities.name: Section 32 tariff revenue
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariff revenue collected under a specific section of U.S. trade law, typically used to support child nutrition programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House proposed redirecting this revenue to sustain WIC during the shutdown, emphasizing its traditional role in supporting vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Section 232 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariffs imposed on imported goods on national security grounds, such as steel, aluminum, and vehicles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The administration initially proposed using Section 232 revenue to fund WIC, but later clarified that it would instead use Section 32 revenue, reflecting policy adjustments during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal food assistance program providing nutrition support to pregnant women, new mothers, and young children
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is central to the story, as the shutdown threatened its operation, and the White House sought to preserve it using tariff funds.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The 47th President of the United States, who has implemented significant tariff policies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump has advocated for increased tariffs to bolster U.S. manufacturing and national security, and his administration is directly responsible for proposing the tariff-based funding for WIC.

namedEntities.name: Karoline Leavitt
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly announced the plan to redirect tariff revenue to WIC and framed it as a response to Democratic inaction during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: House Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Leader of the U.S. House of Representatives, Republican
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He criticized Democrats for enabling the shutdown, which disrupted WIC funding, and highlighted the program’s vulnerability to political gridlock.

namedEntities.name: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Senior Democratic leader in the U.S. Senate
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was cited by House Speaker Johnson as the political figure who triggered the shutdown by refusing to pass spending legislation.

namedEntities.name: National WIC Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The advocacy group representing WIC program stakeholders
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The association expressed concern over the short-term and uncertain nature of the tariff-based funding solution, emphasizing the need for long-term stability.

namedEntities.name: Chris Towner
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He raised legal concerns about the legality of the White House’s use of tariff revenue without congressional appropriation.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency responsible for implementing federal food assistance programs like WIC
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA notified state agencies of funding lapses and allocated up to $150 million in contingency funds to maintain WIC operations.

namedEntities.name: Axios
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Media outlet that first reported on the White House’s tariff funding plan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The story was first reported by Axios, indicating the significance and early attention the policy received in the media landscape.

namedEntities.name: Fiscal Year 2026
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. fiscal year starting October 1, 2025
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The shutdown occurred during the start of FY2026, creating immediate funding gaps for WIC and other federal programs.

namedEntities.name: Infant formula manufacturers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Private companies that produce infant formula and provide rebates to WIC states
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: States can use rebates from these manufacturers as an alternative funding source, supplementing federal support during the shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration announced that it would redirect tariff revenue—specifically from Section 32 and Section 232 tariffs—to fund the WIC program during the government shutdown, which began on October 1, 2025. With Congress failing to pass a spending bill for fiscal year 2026, WIC, which serves nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children, faced imminent closure. The White House, through Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt, justified the move as a necessary intervention to protect vulnerable families, while legal experts and advocacy groups raised concerns about the legality and long-term sustainability of the plan. The National WIC Association emphasized the need for stable, long-term funding, not short-term fixes. Though the USDA provided up to $150 million in contingency funds and state-level rebates, the lack of congressional appropriation raises questions about the legality and effectiveness of the tariff reallocation. The situation has reignited bipartisan concern about the impact of political gridlock on essential social programs.
title: White House says it will use tariff revenue to fund federal food aid for mothers and young children
